column1: Boulogne-Billancourt (French pronunciation: ​[bulɔɲ bijɑ̃kuʁ]; often colloquially called simply Boulogne
column2: until 1924 Boulogne-sur-Seine) is a commune in the western suburbs
column3: and 8 km (5 mi) from the centre
column4: of the French capital Paris. Boulogne-Billancourt is a subprefecture of the Hauts-de-Seine department and the seat of the Arrondissement of Boulogne-Billancourt.

column1: With an average household income in 2013 of €47
column3: nearly twice the French average of €25
column5: Boulogne-Billancourt is one of the wealthiest cities in France.Boulogne-Billancourt is the most populous suburb of Paris and one of the most densely populated municipalities in Europe. Formerly an important industrial site
column6: it has successfully reconverted into business services and is now home to major communication companies headquartered in the Val de Seine business district.

column1: The original name of the commune was Boulogne-sur-Seine (meaning "Boulogne upon Seine").

column2: Boulogne was a small village called Menuls-lès-Saint-Cloud (meaning "Menuls near Saint-Cloud"). In the beginning of the 14th century
column3: King Philip IV of France ordered the building in Menuls-lès-Saint-Cloud of a church dedicated to the virgin of the sanctuary of Boulogne-sur-Mer
column4: then a famous pilgrimage center in northern France. The church
column5: meant to become a pilgrimage centre closer to Paris than the distant city of Boulogne-sur-Mer
column6: was named Notre-Dame de Boulogne la Petite ("Our Lady of Boulogne the Minor"). Gradually
column7: the village of Menuls-lès-Saint-Cloud became known as Boulogne-la-Petite

column2: Boulogne-sur-Seine was officially renamed Boulogne-Billancourt to reflect the development of the industrial neighbourhood of Billancourt annexed in 1860 (see history section below).
it was recorded for the first time in 1150 as Bullencort
column3: sometimes also spelled Bollencort. It comes from Medieval Latin cortem
column7: suffixed to the Germanic patronym Buolo (meaning "friend
column10: thus having the meaning of "estate of Buolo".

column2: the city of Paris was enlarged by annexing neighbouring communes. On that occasion
column3: the communes of Auteuil and Passy were disbanded and divided between Boulogne-Billancourt (then called Boulogne-sur-Seine) and the city of Paris. Boulogne-sur-Seine received a small part of the territory of Passy
column4: and about half of the territory of Auteuil (including the area of Billancourt
column5: which belonged to the disbanded commune of Auteuil).

column1: Some of the shooting events of the 1900 Summer Olympics took place in Boulogne-Billancourt.In 1929
column3: which was hitherto divided between the communes of Boulogne-Billancourt and Neuilly-sur-Seine
column4: was annexed in its entirety by the city of Paris. On that occasion
column6: to which most of the Bois de Boulogne belonged
column7: lost about half of its territory.

column1: Boulogne-Billancourt is known for being the birthplace of three major French industries.

column2: in 1906 for the very first aircraft factory
column3: that of Appareils d'Aviation Les Freres Voisin
column4: which was then followed by those of many other aviation pioneers
column5: and the tradition continues with several aviation related companies still operating in the area.

column1: The automobile industry had a large presence with Renault on Île Seguin
column2: and Salmson building both cars and aircraft engines.
the French film industry started here and
column3: from 1922 to 1992 it was the home of the Billancourt Studios
column4: and since becoming a major location for French film production. It was used as the setting of the TV show Code Lyoko.

column1: The ecologic neighborhood of the Trapèze in Boulogne-Billancourt: the district stands on 74ha and will be able to contain up to 18000 inhabitants at the end of its construction. 65% of the district's energy is brought by geothermal power
column2: which heats and freshens the buildings. Solar panels and a vegetable greenhouse were installed in the aim to link the district to sustainable energies. Bicycle and “soft” travels will of course be put first to reduce the pollution caused by cars
column3: and others vehicles which do not run on electricity.

column1: The Ambroise Paré Hospital is located in the city.

column2: Boulogne-Billancourt is part of the communauté d'agglomération Val de Seine.

column1: Boulogne-Billancourt is served by two stations on Paris Métro Line 10: Boulogne – Jean Jaurès and Boulogne – Pont de Saint-Cloud.
It is also served by three stations on Paris Métro Line 9: Marcel Sembat
Boulogne-Billancourt hosts the global headquarters of several multinational companies
YoplaitPrior to 2000 Schneider Electric's head office was in Boulogne-Billancourt.

column3: Boulogne-Billancourt is a national museum and includes four hectares of gardens
column4: joining together landscape scenes of various national traditions. The museum also includes historic photographs and film.

column1: The Musée des Années Trente is a museum of artistic and industrial objects from the 1930s.

column4: and Jean-Renoir. The public high schools are the Lycée Jacques-Prévert and the Lycée polyvalent Étienne-Jules-Marey. Prior to the September 1968 opening of Prévert

column6: an annex of Lycée La Fontaine served the city.The private school Groupe Scolaire Maïmonide Rambam covers maternelle through lycée. There is also the private high school Notre-Dame. The latter's performance and ranking in Boulogne-Billancourt are given by its success of baccalaureate rate in different series. According to the ranking of L'Express in 2015
column7: the national rank of Notre-Dame de Boulogne was 170 out of 2301 and 7 out of 52 at department level. The private schools Dupanloup and Saint-Joseph-du-Parchamp serve maternelle through collège. Private maternelle and élémentaire schools include Saint-Alexandre and Saint-François d’Assise. Jardin de Solférino and La Maison de l'Enfant are private maternelles.The Association Eveil Japon (エベイユ学園 Ebeiyu Gakuen)
column9: is located in Boulogne-Billancourt. A campus of the École supérieure des sciences commerciales d'Angers is also located in the city.
